statement.tex: \text{Find the integral of the function}\\ \sin^3 x \cos^3 x \\

step.context: \text{Are the following calculations and analysis correct?}
step.tex:
\text{Using trignometric identity,}\\
\begin{align}
\sin^2 x + \cos^2 x &= 1 \\
\implies \sin^3 x \cdot \cos^3 x &= (1- \cos^2 x)\cdot \sin x \cdot \cos^3 x \\ \text{Let } \cos x &= t \text{ then, } -\sin x dx = dt \\ \end{align}\\
\begin{align} \implies (1- \cos^2 x) \cdot \cos^3 x \cdot \sin x &= -(1- t^2) t^3 \\ &= (t^2 -1) t^3 \end{align} \\
\therefore \int \sin^3 x \cos^3 x dx = \int (t^2 -1) t^3 dx
step.reason: \text{Applied the trignometeric identity, }\\ \sin^2 x + \cos^2 x = 1 \text{ and substituted } \cos x =t \\ \text{Check your calculations, if you got something}\\ \text{else.}

step.context: \text{Is the following evaluation of the integral}\\ \int (t^2 -1) t^3 dx \quad \text{correct}?
step.tex: \int (t^2 -1) t^3 dx \\ = \int t^5 dx - \int t^3 dx \\ = \dfrac{t^6}{6} - \dfrac{t^4}{4}+ C \\ \text{Again substituting } t = \cos x \\ = \dfrac{1}{6}\cos ^6 x - \dfrac {1} {4} \cos^4x + C \\ \therefore \int \sin^3 x \cos^3 x = \dfrac{1}{6}\cos ^6 x - \dfrac {1} {4} \cos^4x + C

\int (t^2 -1) t^3 dx \\ = \int t^5 dx - \int t^3 dx \\ = \dfrac{t^5}{5} - \dfrac{t^3}{3}+ C \\ \text{Again substituting } t = \cos x \\ = \dfrac{1}{5}\cos ^5 x - \dfrac {1} {3} \cos^3 x + C \\ \therefore \int \sin^3 x \cos^3 x = \dfrac{1}{5}\cos ^5 x - \dfrac {1} {3} \cos^3 x + C
step.reason: \int x^n dx = \dfrac{x^{n+1}}{n+1} + C \\ \text{ where C is the constant of integration.}
